title: Extra Work on Your Plate
situation: Your manager keeps asking you to ‘quickly’ help with tasks that are not part of your role. Your own work is starting to slip.
question: How do you respond to the next request?

choices.label: Say yes again and plan to work late to catch up.
choices.outcome: Your manager sees you as reliable, but your stress and workload become unsustainable.
choices.insight: Always saying yes can make you look helpful but also silently trains people to overload you.

choices.label: Say, “I can help, but I’ll need to drop something else. Which of my current tasks is less of a priority?”
choices.outcome: Your manager has to consider your workload. Sometimes they reassign the extra task or adjust expectations.
choices.insight: Assertiveness doesn’t always mean saying no; it can mean making trade-offs visible.

choices.label: Avoid your manager and hope they ask someone else instead.
choices.outcome: The pattern might pause, but you miss opportunities to shape how your role is defined.
choices.insight: Avoidance can protect you for a moment but usually leaves the underlying dynamic unchanged.
